text: Light blue sky fills the screen. The CAMERA PANS lower revealing some thin clouds. Finally the CAMERA SPLASHES below the surface of the water and continues to descend. Hundreds of bubbles rise past as the camera swims lazily through azure seas sparkling with sunlight and teeming with brightly colored tropical fish. The bubbles swirl past as we dive down, the water turning paler, the fish becoming duller and more scarce. A large shark swims past us, on the prowl. Deeper and deeper we dive. Soon the water is black as night. Only the faintest slivers of light penetrate down here, and then quickly flicker and die. Large shadowy creatures of the ultra-deep haunt the edges of our vision. Strange luminescent fish with long pointy teeth dart past. The sea bottom draws near, a flat plain scarred by an enormous impact crater, miles in diameter. WE glide over the outer wall, the crater floor looms beneath us. On the bottom, a faint light glimmers. It is an undersea station, a series of five cylinders linked by a central hub. It looks like a giant starfish resting quietly on the ocean floor. Several hundred yards beyond the station, the faint lights of the bio-lab can be seen. This is where all the genetics research is done.
There are bold markings on the side of the docking bay:

Breakfast. Nine people are seated in the galley. Nobody is talking, only the sound of CLANKING dishware. . DR. ABERNATHY glances across at DR. JERKINS. Jerkins is late fourties, high strung. His eyes are a little red and a little swollen. He has the appearance of someone who is not sleeping well at night. Abernathy takes out a small harmonica from his breast pocket. Jerkins freezes in mid-bite at the sight of the harmonica. Abernathy takes his hankerchief, polishing the harmonica. He taps it in his palm, breaking the reeds free. Abernathy puts the harmonica to his lips and and is about to blow... Jerkins starts to say something...

.... when Abernathy slips the harmonica back into his pocket. In some way, he‘has been teasing Jerkins. DIANE NORRIS M.D. has seen-this. She doesn’t find it at all amusing. DREW PIERCE takes a seat at the other end of the table with three of his fellow "support group", JAMES RICHARDSON (Diver), TONY SNYDER (Communications), and JOYCE COLLINS (Diver). There is already a plate of food at his place.
Good morning, campers. (looking down at his plate) . I thought we were out of oatmeal.
That’s eggs... Pierce gingerly shoves them around on his plate, then looks up at Richardson, who is reading a fax letter written in a childish scrawl.
What have you got there, Ace?
Letter from Julie.

Check it out... Collins holds up a fax of a picture drawn in crayon -- it’s a stick figure man in a dive suit adjacent to a house under the water. All around are brightly colored trees, flowers and fish. The caption at the top reads: MY DADDY AT WORK Pierce leans over to get a-look.
Hey, that’s pretty good...
Well, it ain’t Rembrandt, pal...but to me it’s priceless.
Isn’t that sweet?
I told her it was beautiful down here. With flowers and trees... Snyder starts laughing, his mouth gorged with food.
Whata buncha shit...
Must be nice to have a family waiting for you... This is a conversation they’ve had a thousand times, only this time Pierce gives Collins a strange look.
After six months, it’s the only thing that keeps me going.
I could go another six months...as long as they keep laying on that "extra-duty pay".
Come on, admit it, Pierce. Wouldn’t - you like to have a rug-rat of your own waiting for you when you go topside? But Pierce is busy looking at his watch.

Better get the eggheads to work. (standing up, calling to the other end of the table) Let’s go! The bus for the fish factory leaves in five minutes! Valdez, Craven, Abernathy, and Jerkins get up, shuffling towards the hatch. Collins and Richardson also rise. Snyder grabs Richardson’s arm as he starts to leave.
(almost whispering) Did ya get them?
Yeah, I got ’em. You gonna fax my letter to Julie this morning?
You bet. First thing. Richardson glances around the galley to make sure no one is watching, then digs into his pocket. He palms Snyder a small bottle of pills.
If Norris finds out where you got these, you’re dead meat, pal.
She won’t...thanks, man. I owe you one.
(somewhat disgusted) Yeah, yeah.

Hey, I just use them to help me to sleep, you know? Christ, what do you think I am? A fucking junkie? He gives Snyder a scrutinzing stare, then exits the galley. As soon as he is gone, Snyder opens the bottle and pops two of the pills.
(continuing - to himself) Asshole.
As Pierce leads the others into the DSRV, he Pierce starts to sing.
Hi-ho, hi-ho! It’s off to work we go! Come on, eggheads...sing along!
The scientists start to sing, half-heartedly along with Pierce.

Hi-ho, hi-ho! It’s off to work we go! (some funny verse in here) The scientists start to file into the minisub. Laidlaw stands by the airlock, shrugging into his "woolies" -- insulated coveralls. Norris walks up behind hin.
Can I have a word with you, Captain?
Can it wait until I get back from the lab?
It’1ll only take a minute. Laidlaw sighs, nodding his head.
Norris enters the medical bay followed by Laidlaw, she closes the hatch after he is in.
Have you made a decision about rotation yet? Laidlaw leans against the bulkhead, sipping his coffee.
No. Valdez says they’re on the verge of a major breakthrough. He just needs a few more days...
Valdez has been saying that for weeks now. He’s part of the problem...he’s pushing too hard. (then) I think we should rotate the whole science team out.
What’s another week?

To a veteran like you...nothing. But these men aren’t Navy, they’re scientists. They’ve been trapped ina can at the bottom of the ocean for more than six months now. They need a break. (beat) I don’t want to go over your head on this...
(shrugs) Look, Doctor...it’s your call...
I’m telling you...I’m worried about them. Laidlaw takes a moment to think.
Tell you what...why don’t we review these requests on a case by case basis?
Fine. Here’s a list...
(reading over the list) Why do you want to transfer Collins?
(simply) She’s pregnant.
Does he know?
Of course she knows, she asked me to run the...
I said, does he know. Does Pierce know?
She doesn’t want to tell him.
(surprised) Why not? ° NORRIS I don’t know. He’s not my friend. Laidlaw is cut off by the videocom BUZZER. He crosses to the panel and punches the XMIT switch.
(into videocom) Laidlaw... Pierce’s face blinks on the tiny monitor.
(filtered) We’re ready to pull out, Captain.
I’m on my way. (to Norris) Let’s talk about this when I get back.
I’1l be here. CcuT TO:
Laidlaw enters the hatch to the DSRV.

Laidlaw crawls into the mini-sub. It’s very cramped. Pierce is in the pilot’s seat in the conning tower, donning a headset. He starts flipping switches, humming quietly to himself. Collins sits directly beneath Pierce, surrounded by video monitors, sonar equipment, recorders, etc. To her left is the cluster of forward viewing ports. They are covered to protect them from scratching.

In the passenger section in back, Drs. Valdez, Craven, Abernathy, and Jerkins are already strapped in. Laidlaw takes his seat next to Collins, activating his monitors. Three screens labeled: PORT FORWARD STARBD flicker to life. Pierce calls down to Richardson.

Close us up. Richardson closes the hatch, sealing them in. Pierce works more controls, we hear a loud WHIRR, then a metallic THUD. The DSRV start to sway back and forth as it drifts free of the Deepstar. Pierce breaks from his humming into a song.
«++SO we sailed on to the sun, ‘til we found a sea of green...
Oh, God please. Not again.
(starts to sing MUCH louder) - -+-and we lived beneath the waves in a yellow SUBMARINE! In back, we can HEAR Abernathy join in on harmonica.
As Pierce SINGS and Abernathy PLAYS, the minisub sails across the vast crater to the dim lights of the not-too-distant BIO-LAB. cuT TO:

CLOSE ON A DISPLAY SCREEN -- The Advanced Seafloor Profile Sonar -- ASIPS -- a grid of green lines that outline the contour of the seafloor, slowly marching towards us, like an animated 3-D geodetic survey map.
Contact in five-hundred meters and closing. Laidlaw concentrates on the constantly shifting sonar display.
Two hundred meters. Pierce backs off on the throttle, the engine WHINING down as he hits the navigation lights.
Two powerful work lights blaze to life on the minisub, their beams scattered by suspended particles in the water. Ahead, the shadowy form of the Bio-Lab looms up.
On the ASIPS, the computer graphic image of the Bio-Lab nearly fills the screen. An animated overlay gives docking instructions to Pierce.
(continuing) Fifty meters...forty... Pierce keeps one eye out the viewport and one eye on his instruments as he carefully maneuvers the minisub alongside the station.
(continuing) ..-thirty...twenty...ten...
The minisub slips slowly into place next to the docking ring.
The DSRV mates to the docking ring with a reverberating CLANG. Laidlaw presses the AIRLOCK PURGE switch and we HEAR the ROAR of compressed air.
The compressed air purges the airlock free of water.
Everybody leaves the sub.

Valdez and Craven turn on monitoring equipment while Collins hits the lights. Through the glass wall of the control room, the bio-lab lights flicker on, revealing the vast experimental laboratory. Abernathy and Jerkins, zipping up their sterile suits, step into the "HOT BOX".

The "Hot Box" is the long narrow corridor for disinfecting persons entering or leaving the bio lab. At either end there are two small pressure doors, set high off the deck. Abernathy and Jerkins move silently through the "Hot Box". Neither speaks or looks at the other.
Laidlaw and Valdez watch through the control room window as Abernathy and Jerkins go to work, setting up the day’s experiments.
How close are you, John?
Any day now we should have a breakthrough.
Norris is putting a lot of pressure on me to rotate your team out.
You can’t let her do that, Captain.
She’s threatening to go over my head.
All I need is a few more days.
I can’t run interference for you much longer. Let’s go, Pierce. Pierce and Laidlaw head for the docking bay.
Pierce and Laidlaw are crossing the docking bay, headed back for the minisub.
Look, I don’t like butting into other people’s problems...
Uh, oh. Is this a Captain/Sailor or Father/Son talk?
More like nosey fuck to dickhead. Pierce "ahhhs" in recognition.

(continuing) It seems to me that you had something nice going with Collins and then you just let it die. Collins is great gal and she’s crazy about you, so I ask myself "why is Pierce acting like an asshole?" Pierce scowls.
It didn’t work out...so what? Happens everyday.
Don’t you think you owe her an explaination?
What’s there to explain?

Drew, I was there when you got married, I was there when she died, I was there when you put her in the ground. I know how much you loved her, but you can’t let Kathy’s death hold up the rest of your life. You’ve got to get on with...
(cutting him off) Okay, you’ve spoken your piece. Thank you very much. Pierce starts to leave.
Want some advice?
No.
Tough, here it comes anyway...give the thing with Collins another chance.
Is that an order?
No, it’s just advice...good advice. Just then, Craven enters the docking bay from the control room.
Captain, you better come quick...it’s Jerkins!
Craven, Laidlaw, and Pierce re-enter the control room. Valdez and Collins watch Jerkins storm around the bio-lab through the window.
Okay John, what’s the problem?
It’s Jerkins...he’s trapped Dr. Abernathy in the dive well and locked us out of the lab. He says he won’t come out until he gets to talk to you.
(to Collins) Can you get into the lab?
. He’s pressurized the hatch. We can cut through it, but it’1ll take time.
Let me talk to hin. Laidlaw presses the intercom button.
Robby. This is Captain Laidlaw.
Captain! I want to go home right now! If you don’t send me home right now I’m going to flood the airlock and kill that noisy fat bastard!
Just settle down, Robby. Dr. Norris has already told me you want to go home and I’ve been working on that.
Norris said I could go home a month ago!
I know, Rob. I know. And we are going to send you home...
(into intercom) All I’m asking for is a few more days...
I want to go RIGHT NOW!!! I’m sick of this place! I’m sick of these stupid experiments! And I’m sick and fucking tired of Abernathy and THAT STUPID
Okay, Rob! Okay! (to Valdez) John, just butt out a second...Collins, patch me into the airlock.

I just want to make sure he’s okay, Rob. Let me do that, okay...just let me make sure he’s okay. (to Collins) Tie in the airlock. Collins flips some switches.
As the airlock camera flickers to life. Abernathy leans against the airlock wall.
Eddie, are you okay?

Now Dr. Jerkins, how about letting Dr. Abernathy out of the airlock. He’s promised not to bother you with his harmonica anymore. Okay?

Jerkins!

Captain, we have to get him out of there before he does something stupid. If he harms those specimens, we could lose weeks of hard work.

(to Valdez) Okay...you try. Valdez switches the speaker back on.

derkins, nobody has asked you to compromise anything here. You’re part of the scientific elite and we’re on the verge of a new age. -

Jerkins shakes the sea creature at the monitor, it SCREECHES again as his grip tightens.
(continuing) And what about 1138?!! What good is that thing to anyone? He gestures to a large cryogenic chamber, frozen vapor trailing off its side. A large red sign on the door reads:
1138 was a mistake, I admit that. But...
They’re ALL mistakes!
Mistakes are important steps in the scientific process...
No!! We don’t know what we’re doing!!! Can’t you see that?!! ARE YOU BLIND?!! Just at that moment, Dr. Abernathy starts up with a chorus of "Mary had a little lamb." Jerkins goes beserk.
(screaming into the airlock)

And with that, Jerkins heaves the SQUEALING sea creature in the direction of the airlock. It hits the control panel, where it crashes against the PURGE button with a loud SPLAT! SURGE Sutton with a ioud SPLAT.

Laidlaw, Collins, and Pierce watch helplessly.
Holy shit...
Abernathy struggles, drowning in the swirling frigid water. With a deafening WOOSH of compressed air, the dive well purges. .
The airlock door opens, flushing Dr. Abernathy to the sea.
Valdez’ jaw drops to the floor. Craven gasps and makes the sign of the cross.
Jerkins stares at the airlock control panel with a blank expression. His mind can’t comprehend what has just happened.
Laidlaw is the first to get over the shock. He turns to Collins and Pierce.
Okay, get him out of there. cuT To:

Collins cutting through the hatch.

Pierce opens the door’s emergency access panel and pulls down on a handle. There is a HISS of compressed air escaping, but the door doesn’t move. Crouching down next to the hatch, Pierce gets a handhold on the hatch and strains to lift it. The door slowly GRINDS open, but it’s clear it won’t stay that way on its own. Pierce peers through the ever widening slit in the door, while on the other side...

Laidlaw and Valdez are pulling up on the hatch, Dr. Craven stands behind then. As soon as the hatch is high enough, Pierce props it open with his shotgun and steps inside.
What the hell is going on?
Jerkins opened 1138...I heard him scream...and then the lights went out. Then the door closed and sealed.
They do that automatically when the power dies. (then) Where’s Collins?

She was in the bio-lab...with Jerkins. Pierce dashes for the hatch to the "Hot Box". He pulls down the manual handle and spins the undogging wheel. Laidlaw points to the red light blinking over the door.
You’ve got a fire in there.
Don’t go in! He yanks the hatch open. Smoke rolls. He peers into the hot box.
Lights are out in there... Pierce grabs an EBS unit and a handlight off the wall and steps inside.
Laidlaw curses, pulls the second shotgun from the hatch -- it closes -- grabs an EBS and follows Pierce.
Pierce steps down into about two feet of water, his flashlight stabbing through the thick smoke that fills the "Hot Box". As he starts wading through the knee-deep water, Laidlaw comes up behind him.
Goddamn it! You’ve compromised the whole station. There’s procedures for dealing with...
Piss on procedure. They look at each other, then Laidlaw shrugs as if to say "what the fuck" and hands Pierce a shotgun.
(continuing - over his shoulder to Valdez) Dr. Valdez, what the fuck does this 1138 look like?
Well, it’s a segmented exoskeltoid, roughly symmetrical...
(cutting him off) I mean...does it have teeth or what?
Oh...yes. Several thousand very sharp teeth.
(under his breath) You had to ask. Suddenly, Pierce freezes as his flashlight beam picks up something floating in the water.
Pierce’s beam plays over_a_ large clump of blood and goo, coming to rest on a face recognizable only by the broken pair of glasses that hangs near the end.
What the hell is that?
It’s Dr. Jerkins...I think. As Pierce looks up A_BLACK WRITHING SHAPE SUDDENLY
Pierce and Laidlaw SHOUT in fear, staggering back.
They both fire at the shape, blasting it down into the water. The gunshots ECHO through the small corridor for a moment as Valdez yells:
Did you get it?

(grinning) Yeah, I think I killed it. Pierce prods the thing carefully with his shotgun, then picks up the riddled body of a creature, shining his light on it. Valdez peers down from the hatch, takes one look, and:
No, that’s 1257. It can’t hurt you. Pierce tosses the ugly motherfucker back in the water.
Goddamn right. He and Laidlaw ease through the cut-out hatch into the bio-lab.

Pierce sweeps his flashlight across the lab, cutting through the sprinkler system’s rainy drizzle. One side of the lab is burned, covered in a blanket of foam. Some of the specimen tanks are broken open, others have been blackened from the smoke.
zzzzzzt! POW! crackle. The flashlight beam follows the NOISE, coming to rest on the power control bus. It has been smashed. Sparks still arc from the loose wires. Insulation still burns.

Yeah. Looks like something smashed into it. He looks over the control panel, finds the EMERGENCY BATTERY switch, and flips it ON. . Harsh red emergency lights flicker on, giving them a better view. They search the lab.
Collins? Collins... There is no sign of her.
Pierce...

(sighs) Norris was right...Christ, what a mess. I better go call topside...tell them we have a problen. He looks at Pierce.

Okay,..stay sharp. Laidlaw turns and leaves the lab. Pierce watches him go. He leans up against one of the larger plex specimen containers, the back of his shirt wiping away some of the foam and carbon.
In the specimen tank, breathing off an EBS unit. She looks out.

Totally unaware that Collins is right behind hin. Suddenly a loud THUMPING on the tank propels him to his feet, shotgun up and ready as he spins. He sees Collins and can’t believe it. Setting the shotgun down he climbs up on top of the tank.
Pierce reaches into the tank and grabs Collins’ wrists and pulls her up. She grins, their eyes lock.
Nice timing. My EBS unit was almost empty.
Pierce softens, a wave of relief rushes over his face. He holds her gaze for a moment, it looks like they might embrace. Then Pierce breaks the spell...
Don’t mention it.

(worried) Didn’t you kill it?
